posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Are PCIe Gen 4 and 5 memes for the average consumer? When you look at loading times between Gen 4 and Gen 3 NVMe SSDs, they differ very little. PC startup time it's the same. Even high end GPUs are not bottlenecked by PCIe 3;0, so who exactly benefits from the new generations of PCIe capabilities besides servers that just want to split the lanes to fight 30 more storage devices or whatever it is? I was wondering because even if you are a data hoarder, dealing with shitzillions of large files, wouldn't it make sense to use high capacity HDDs instead of a Gen4 SSD?

I just don't get it, it seems like to the home consumer market those newer PCIe revisions are more about marketing and those am5 motherboard prices are retarded because of the need to have more PCB layers to accommodate a feature that has no fucking use to the average joe. What I typed above pretty much dismantles the whole muh futureproofing angle.

Not saying they're pushing this to rip people off, but it's not something that really benefits the average consumer, it's just something the datacenter market wants and we gotta live with it regardless if it's any benefit to the home computer portion of the market. I know some people talk about directstorage, well Microshit has been propping that up for like 5 years or whatever, I'll believe that shit matters when I see it

Assign a bit to every letter, if the bit is set, the character is uppercase, otherwise lowercase.

In this case we have 12 letters, 2^12=4096 combinations.

Wayland compositors have decided that linux specific apis should be part of wayland api.

I actually like systemd. I know that some people have legitimate concerns about scope creep and prefer s6 or other less bloated inits, but for me systemd has made system administration easier and more reliable. It just works and has been working for years.
I haven't used pipewire but I know that many people have been having a positive experience with it too.
Absolutely fuck Wayland though, they've just pushed the complexity that X11 had into compositors and made fragmentation much worse. Now instead of just having xrandr or setxkbmap, you need a GNOME version, a KDE version, a wlroots version... Even if they managed to rectify this and other design flaws like their render loop from another galaxy, the project is fundamentally untrustworthy. They've been promoting themselves as the future of the Linux desktop while rejecting every feature that the average GNOME/GTK normie doesn't need or intentionally bikeshedding it for fucking years. True fractional scaling, turning off vsync - these are not even that hard, they just don't fit into the Wayland devs' muh perfect design. Contempt for the user must never be rewarded.

This, so much this. Peoople crying about how verbose Java is usually confuse it with best practices and patterns. Some examples:

You CAN write Java without specifying class, method or variable visibility at all.

You CAN write Java without ever doing interfaces or extends.

You CAN write Java without long package names.

You CAN write Java without even declaring types (since 10)

You CAN write Java without ever declaring classes other than mandatory starting point file with main.

>>90997697
>It's better to buy an M.2 PCIe NVME SSD with DRAM or just DRAM-Less?
DRAM is always better, but the difference is much smaller because PCIe 4x is fast enough to access system memory in reasonable time.
>Also, instead of DRAM, why not use the system RAM?
It does, but this leeches memory bandwidth from the CPU and imposes extra synchronization waits on the drive controller.

A lot of the people with work experience just write and maintain shitty line-of-business CRUD apps, which few people here ask questions about. at least thats what I did back when I worked in the field.

>>90998660
The network interfaces and routing table are system-wide on both Windows and Linux, having one program use one interface and another program use another requires some kind of policy-based routing setup. It's a pain on Linux and I have no idea how you'd do it on Windows.

also running Tor through your VPN is very much a valid use case: it prevents your ISP from knowing that you're using Tor. There was a college kid who got caught and arrested for making a fake bomb threat that way. He did it over Tor, but it turns out only one person on the whole campus network was connected to Tor when the threat was sent. So don't send bomb threats, but more prosaically this is useful in places that block or try to fuck with Tor, of which there are quite a few.

>>91000947
>prioritize range
Any cheap b/g/n will do as they use the 2.4GHz band, just pick one with detachable antennas and put some big ones in it.
>what do I need to consider in terms of futureproofing?
There is no future future proofing for 2.4GHz, shit's going to be 5GHz.
>is mesh wifi a meme?
Certainly not for someone who needs mesh. Mesh is infinitely better than using repeaters.
>devices can't reliably and automatically switch between the two as one would expect them to
This isn't the access point' fault, it's the connecting devices OS network management being primitive as they stick to whatever 'still works' and won't change until complete disconnection. And it's the 2.4GHz with its long range being one culprit, ideally you'd have many 5GHz access points around your house.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91008478
>Linux distro.
Consult your distro' guides. The idea is that the unencrypting happens via tools inside the initramfs.
>I guess I did. What's the need for a TPM then?
TPM can make it machine specific as in you couldn't just take the drive, plug it into another computer and decrypt it.
Think of TPM as a smartcard like a credit or SIM card that does shit with the public key.

>Free beginner resources to get started with HTML, CSS, JavaScript and PHP
https://eloquentjavascript.net/Eloquent_JavaScript.pdf - A modern introduction to JavaScript

>increase/decrease the margin-left attribute
pajeet tier answer
>>90968676
>remove the ugly scrollbar
if you want to also keep scroll functionality you can use
.no-scrollbar {
  -ms-overflow-style: none; /* IE and Edge */
  scrollbar-width: none; /* Firefox */
}
.no-scrollbar::-webkit-scrollbar {
  display: none; /* Chrome, Safari and Opera */
}

maybe also scroll-snap-type: x mandatory and scroll-snap-align: start on all children, this way you maintain scrolling functionality on mobile
>left and right arrows that perform the same actions
keep a reference to the DOM node you want to scroll, add two buttons with an onclick function like this
const node = document.querySelector('...')
let current = 0
scrollHandler = (offset) => {
  current += offset
  const x = node.children[current].offsetLeft
  node.scroll({left:x, behavior: 'smooth'})
}

posts.com:
I import this utility function to my main component in Typescript.

When i assign zoomIn(1.5, 2) to an element , typescript gets very angry because it doesn't know what the fuck these properties are. Can I define types from an imported function via zooomIn.delay: string; for example or what the fuck do I do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90982168
You have to add type annotations to the parameters of that function, i.e.
export const zoomIn = (delay: number, duration: number) => ....

// Component.tsx
import { zoomIn } from "./path/to/utils";

zoomIn(0, 1500);


Sometimes, like in this case I'd prefer using an object instead because it's easier to skim read and won't result in misplacement of function parameters (e.g. you placed the duration number in the delay param and vice versa)

export const zoomIn = (options: { delay: number, duration: number }) => ....

// Component.tsx
import { zoomIn } from "./path/to/utils";

zoomIn({
  duration: 1500,
  delay: 0,
});

>what are the pros and cons of React?
pros:
lots of jobs, huge ecosystem, battle tested in prod on many fortune 500 company websites

cons:
lots of footguns that can result in poor performance
useEffect is the bane of every react dev's existence
contexts are not extremely intuitive, it sometimes requires the dev to know in advance the DOM tree structure of how it's being nested

>Astro, the way I understand it, can help with the optimization and delivery of the web, I'm not worried about performance if I use React modules with it, but seems like learning React first is a good idea given all the support it seems to have

Yep, kind of. By default, Astro will just server render all your react components (i.e. nothing will have interactivity), and you have to explicitly opt in to hydration (i.e. including the component's JS for interactivity) by using "client:xxx" directives on a component-by-component basis (which they call "Islands Architecture") in an "xxxx.astro" file.

>>90983937
>but seems like JS is a real performance problem
For a large part, performance issues can be to do with integrating external stuff like support chat boxes, analytics, ads, etc.

People nowadays are trying to optimise their JS as much as possible, partly because we now have sophisticated tools to score page performance metrics on mobile and desktop, and Google uses these to punish poor performers on search. Your site will have just as bad perf issues if you have unoptimised images for example.

>>90977767
Next allows you to do server side rendering and statically generated pages. Avoid that stuff until you have at least some experience using the useEffect and other hooks.
Since the pages are rendered on the server, useEffect is ran, but only once. In a browser you expect it to change something which won't take effect when you render on the backend.

It is not too bad, just read up about how to use the hooks with Next SSG and SSR.

>>90998005
>Because?
I actually have technical reasons for disliking Neuralink rather than dumb political/etc. ones.

The current approach to a brain-machine interface they're using (conductive wires "electrodes" implanted in the brain of a subject) is lousy for a few different reasons, the main one to me being the fact that neurons are extremely small, especially compared to the electrodes themselves which are hundreds, if not thousands of times larger than individual neurons and as such can't match the resolution of an implementation with 1:1 electrode-neuron connections. A single electrode is reading/writing electrical signals to tens/hundreds of thousands of neurons simultaneously (not including the ones that were destroyed in the process of implantation). All the signals combined in parallel might equal a fuzzy picture if they were used in the visual cortex to overlay images in your vision compared to a sharp, accurate image.
I know its still young technology. Hopefully we either get better technologies for implanting smaller electrodes, or find a way to very precisely interact with the brain indirectly with electromagnetic machines... somehow.

They have to start somewhere. They could wait another 10-20 years or simply leap into the tech thats demonstrated the best, a surgical BCI thats already been in use for few decades and make rapid progress there. Its not like they're locked into the system, the system will change if they find something better/cheaper/easier/robust way to do things another way.

What they want is a minimum viable product with a roadmap that can scale up to future iterations of the product. Given that the current system has been shown to work on animals as they are now, it means its a right product to make.

The final point is the value extracted out of current implementation vs time spent wasted doing r/d on some other exotic way of doing things. So while its not perfect cure for everything, its a cure for value given time/money/approval as FDA's limiting factor.

>>90999388
That anon's comment has a kernel of truth. There's a minority of old people who miss communism, not just out of nostalgia but because life was genuinely simpler for a certain type of person who had no ambition and wanted to live their whole life on autopilot. You went to school, had a high school sweetheart who you'd maybe marry later, you got recommended a job and took it, and you could keep it your whole life if you put in a token effort and didn't go against the party line. You'd buy the same shit as everyone because there was nothing else available. No 10 brands for every item, just "bread" and "coffee"... if they even had coffee that day. You'd chit-chat and socialize with your neighbors in hours-long queues for basic items like blankets or shoes. A life of zero decisions.
Of course the country was poor as shit. Central economic planning instead of a market system meant frequent fuckups like a factory getting lots of nuts but too few bolts, or a grocery store having full shelves of vinegar but no meat. Promotions depended mostly on politics so there was little incentive to work efficiently, or even be nice to customers.
Capitalism has brought an enormous increase in the standard of living but also the burden of constantly making decisions. Most people think this has been a very good trade.
t. >>90999385

People call it RAII but it sounds like reference counting with escape analysis to optimize trivial cases, which is different because it doesn't give hard guarantees about when an object is destroyed.
The beauty of C and Rust and C++ is that they can operate entirely without a runtime. You know for sure when memory is allocated and freed, and you can interoperate with other languages without overhead because there's nothing you can't touch. It's qualitatively different. You could argue about how commonly that's needed, of course, but it doesn't sound like Nim can go there without --gc:none, and it sounds like a lot of the language disappears with --gc:none.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90986403
>>somehow this is the fault of the language
I dunno if it's """the fault of the language""", I don't like to play the blame game, but it's something you have to mention. Usually when people talk about turning off Nim's GC they're very casual about it. "It's just not the default" is one thing, "you'll basically be writing a different language with a separate ecosystem" is another.
>destruction is deterministic though, when a shared object leaves the scope the compiler injects a refcount operation and a destructor call for when the refcount hits 0.
When a language has RAII I can trivially tell how long an object lives. If it goes out of scope it's destroyed. Or maybe it's moved somewhere else, and I can track its lifetime there.
When a language has reference counting I don't have a clue in the general case. Maybe it's supposed to be destroyed when it goes out of scope. Maybe it's supposed to be captured by some other object. Maybe it's supposed to be captured in some cases and be destroyed in others. Maybe it's supposed to be destroyed but it was actually accidentally captured and it's going to live for a while yet. Who knows?
This is a different model with a different structure. It just doesn't end up similar in practice.
I remember a C++-ish research language that crashes if an object's refcount hasn't reached zero when it goes out of scope. That still counts as RAII in my book, but Nim doesn't.
>that's the case with nim as well, at most you need a call to GC_ref before passing the object around to be sure it won't be collected when someone else decreases the ref count
That's a pretty big deal! People write shared C libraries in Rust and (of course) C++. Some other language owns the process but it calls into your C/Rust/C++ and everything's dandy. Would you do that in Nim? How many of its garbage collectors are even compatible with that?

It’s true that LLVM can output WASM, and it’s true that they build the bootstrap compiler by targeting WASM. All the other stuff you said is either inaccurate to what they’re actually doing, or outright nonsensical. The C backend is separate from the WASM backend. C is not C++. It also does not use C as an intermediate language to feed to LLVM (that’s not how you fucking use LLVM in the general case and you’re really showing your ass here).
There are two major parts of this process that do use C. One of them is a custom WASM-to-C compiler that does not depend on the system LLVM at all (it works with any C compiler). The other is the next stage, where the Zig compiler is compiled to C, which likewise does not depend on the system LLVM at all (it works with any C compiler).
All of this is spelled out really fucking clearly in the post you linked. You can’t read. Suck a dick in a restaurant.

I think [_]u0{} marks an any-length array of unsigned 0-bit integers, and then ** must be the repetition operator. Then they're consumed with |element, index| but since the element is uninteresting you only use the index.
0-bit integers don't take up any space (hopefully) so it doesn't blow up your memory.

>[_]u0{0}

>[_]u0{0} ** n
repeat it n times
>for ([_]u0{0} ** n) |_, i|

>>91001963
>i've never heard anyone say scoped threads was cringe
Having just absorbed what they are, they are absolutely cringe.
From what I can tell, it's a bullshit convoluted work around for the fact you can just spawn a thread and put a lifetime on the handle returned because you can't add lifetimes to non-pointer things.
There's no real reason (as far as I understand) why you shouldn't just be able to capture whatever you want in a thread and just a lifetime in the return type.
Something like this:
struct Handle<F, T>(F)
where
    F: FnOnce() -> T;
trait Joinable<T> {
    fn join(self) -> T;
}
impl<F, T> Joinable<T> for Handle<F, T>
where
    F: FnOnce() -> T,
{
    fn join(self) -> T {
        self.0()
    }
}
fn spawn<F, T>(f: F) -> impl Joinable<T>
where
    F: FnOnce() -> T + Send,
    T: Send,
{
    Handle(f)
}
fn test_handle<'a>(arg: &'a Vec<i32>) -> impl Joinable<i32> + 'a {
    spawn(Box::new(|| arg[0]))
}
fn main() {
    let mut a = vec![1, 2, 3];
    println!("{}", test_handle(&a).join());
    let b = spawn(|| a.push(23));
    b.join();
    a.push(2);
    println!("{:?}", a);
}

I am not trying to prove that Rust is not bloated. What is bloat is subjective and there will always be people who think that everything more than C is bloat.
What I am trying to say is that there is different approach to adding new things to the language. In contrast to C++, Rust doesn't add features for no reason beside including more paradigms. And this is evident based on all the popularly requested features that even though could be easily added, will never be so.
That's literally all I'm saying. Will that result in bloat in the future? I'm certain that some people already consider it bloated. But I don't care, because what's important for me is not having tons of half assed features forced into language just to be forgotten and abandoned on the large pile of good but ultimately useless and underdeveloped additions. Maybe it will end up like this, but I honestly doubt it because of how careful they are with including new things(at least appear so in my eye)

I'd say the only real benefit to using something like Protonmail is that you can be somewhat assured your email provider isn't snooping through your emails, that's the only reason I use it. There's a third-party IMAP bridge available, but it breaks every other day so it's basically useless. I dunno, I want to find a better email solution at some point, but switching over emails is such a pain in the cock and I don't really know what I'd switch to. >Why do people keep thinking that AI is racist when the people it gets info from are mostly racist themselves?
Because AI does not exist, machine learning exists. Even a bot in counter strike or any other video game is an AI. These machine learning input fields, that which you luddites all over the world - really, everywhere - call "AI" are search engines. They indexed content. Then you enter a search term. The index gets searched, content gets found. Now something happens, which is apparently not as emphasized with regular web search engines like yahoo: the search results get fed into a neural network. This neural network has a shape. The shape comes from the content you fed into it. For these "AI"s of you failures, the neural network model learned in which way sentences and words are ordered. Which words come first? Which last? Which words are usually to be found in front of others? Exclamation marks get put where? The trick is not programming those structures manually by hand, but making the machine adapt, learn, those structures by itself.
Now this neural network runs over the search results and orders the words according to it's learned and adapted model, which makes it print out sentences. Sentences with correct grammar. Because "it" learned from people that wrote properly. If the people wrote gangslang and gibberish, the "AI" would also write like that.
If people would have posted yottabytes of hentai where the character has tits on their backs, the "AI" would draw hentai with tits on their backs.

So, you are absolutely gay and retarded. What you call an AI, I call a search algorithm. What you call machine learning I call automation.
Because I'm not some pretentious fuck that constantly cries for attention and investors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hello /aosg/, I present you my beloved OS, Hoshi. I've been working on it since 2015 and at this moment it can self compile and run various custom software that I'm using. There is no code available nor an ISO because I haven't decided what I'm going to do with it so far. Considering I have a custom filesystem I'm tempted at writing a custom encryption layer for it.
It is POSIX-compliant because initially I wanted to be able to easily port software to it but things changed and later I decided to write everything from scratch, including any userspace applications so for now the POSIX layer is just extra baggage.
To give a basic idea of the structure, there is a first-stage bootloader that loads the second-stage bootloader which passes info to the microkernel and loads it. The microkernel forks an init-like process that loads the UI compositor server and transfers execution to it. Everything is configurable and you can skip the compositor and just get console access. It's basic OS 101, nothing fancy.
More info https://sizeof.cat/project/hoshi/ if you have any questions do ask.
PS. There will never be Rust in the kernel so don't even ask about it.

>>90983920
I was briefly experimenting with this. Obviously one needs to use the MMU to implement a full Unix (with fork() and suchlike). I noticed that Amigas mostly only use the lower 2gb of memory, where almost everything is mapped into and thus only area that Workbench uses, and figured I could use the Transparent Translation feature of the 68040/68060 MMU (and I presume the 68030 has similar, but otherwise one could just use an identity mapping.)
Complexity arises because I was finding that the MMU was often already being programmed (perhaps by 68040.library/68060.library) which I didn't analyse further. But regardless I think a Unix environment complete with fork() is practical to implement running alongside Workbench. I think one could reserve the top 1gb for the Unix kernel, and the next lower 1gb for Unix apps (though I don't know if the 68k MMUs deny user-mode access to the upper half of memory, if so that complicates matters) and that should work fine. I have my own (simplistic) hobby Unix-like and would welcome the opportunity to collaborate with someone expert on the Amiga to implement a Unix environment for Amigas that runs in tandem with Workbench.

>>91001572
>>91001586
Kinda neat. That's using the CPU on the daughterboard instead of the normal CPU, right? I can't imagine Windows XP would be able to deal with a NUMA architecture.

The thing that inspired me was this machine https://enzian.systems/assets/publications/enzian-asplos-2022.pdf which was mentioned in a YouTube video in one of the earlier threads. Apparently the university that designed it went through a lot of pains to get low-level access to all of the logic blocks on the chip, and the management controller runs Linux on a couple of Cortex A9 cores in order to give them direct control over shit like power states that normally happens below the OS level. I think how this works though is that they SSH from the OS running on the processor to the one on the board management controller and then change settings that way.

I was just thinking how cool would it be if an OS had direct access to everything, everywhere, and it could boot instantly to a desktop instead of a BIOS splash and then start making stuff like input devices, storage devices, and compute devices available as they're initialized.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91003396
Yeah it bypasses the normal CPU, Xeon Phi is probably the closest we have to this card these days. As for that paper, the idea of having an OS that just has access to everything and direct resources as needed is a really neat idea. Like you said offloading all the system management tasks to an external controller and then just booting into an OS would be sick. I'm sure if they used a fast enough FPGA they could adapt to a wide variety of scenarios.

110V at a constant resistance of 1000 ohms = 12.1W
220V at a constant resistance of 1000 ohms = 48.4W

If you double the voltage, current goes up twice but power quadruples. To achieve the same 12.1W power, you would need 4000 ohms at 220V. We use 230V so for us it's 52.9W at 1000 ohm load.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90987554
Yes but no. Power source can either try to maintain a constant voltage or constant amperage, usually the former, up to maximum load (whatever it's trying to keep constant will vary a bit anyway). With mains you can assume the voltage is constant, resistance is the property of whatever comes in contact with it (e.g. your body[1]), amperage only follows from that. So yeah, while amperage is correlated with your body getting fried, voltage is correlated with that in the same way. It's hard to say that one or the other is any more responsible for the damage but voltage is the thing you know about the power supply here.

Also, apart from burning you, AC can make your muscles spasm really hard and cause serious injuries that way. And make you grip whatever is shocking you very hard. And stop your heart with those spasms. Great tip: if you're going to get shocked, try to not have the current flow between opposing limbs (actually I think there are some guidelines which limbs you should use when tinkering with voltage (which should be off but in case it's not)).

[1] resistance will also depend on what parts of your body are in contact and in what state it's in -- e.g. sweaty or dehydrated -- both of which will affect the path of current through your body.

That's complicated
https://www.electricaltechnology.org/2021/11/1-phase-supply-is-230v-why-3-phase-400v-not-690v.html
More voltage is more power over same wire crossection. So it's 400v bettwen phases for 3 phase system. This is how it comes from the transformer to user. Heavy industrial machines that can tap up to 47 kwt from single outlet get all 3 phases.
But for residence and appliances in the vicinity of people 400v is too dangerous, they get ony 1 phase wire and it's 240V.
All comes from the same transformer. Difference is only how you connect wires.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I use Ubuntu and after a update "Open in Terminal" stopped showing in the FM, how do I fix this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This issue may be caused by a missing package or a configuration problem. One solution is to reinstall the package "nautilus-open-terminal" which provides the "Open in Terminal" feature. You can do this by running the following command in the terminal:


sudo apt-get install --reinstall nautilus-open-terminal

After the installation is complete, you may need to restart the file manager (Nautilus) for the changes to take effect. You can do this by running the following command:

nautilus -q

If the problem persists, you can try uninstalling and reinstalling the nautilus package, or reset the nautilus configuration.


sudo apt-get remove nautilus
sudo apt-get install nautilus

or

mv ~/.config/nautilus ~/.config/nautilus.bak

Please note that this will remove all your nautilus settings and preferences.

posts.com: What is the difference between libadwaita and gtk?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90967435
My imoutodaughterwife Maya.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90968317
libadwaita and GTK (GIMP Toolkit) are both libraries used in the development of graphical user interfaces (GUIs) for Linux and Unix-like operating systems.

GTK (GIMP Toolkit) is a multi-platform toolkit for creating graphical user interfaces. It provides a set of widgets, or user interface elements, that developers can use to build their applications. GTK is widely used in Linux and Unix-like operating systems to create graphical user interfaces for a variety of applications, including the Gnome desktop environment.

libadwaita is a theme library for GTK+ 3.0 and above, that provides the default look and feel for the Gnome desktop environment. It provides CSS styles, icons, and other visual elements that are used by GTK+ widgets to provide a consistent look and feel across all Gnome applications.

In short, GTK is a library to build GUI and libadwaita is the default theme library for GTK that provides the look and feel of Gnome desktop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90974721
Not that anon but of course it's technically possible for there to be malware.

But it just doesn't really ever happen, because it's a question of practicality.
For example you're asking about wine, so think how an attacker would have to target your system. They would have to create Windows software that has GNU/Linux exploits embedded in it for the sole purpose of targetting anyone running it through wine.
And on top of that do they target wine or proton? Which distro do they target? And even among users of the same distro our systems are highly varied with totally different combinations of desktop software, window managers, startup systems, etc.
So whatever exploit they use is going to have a tiny surface area (i.e. a tiny amount of users that are vulnerable to their very specific attack) that it's not even worth the effort, and has a low probability of working on your specific machine anyway.

Also GNU/Linux is inherently more secure than windows. Software is installed as root but run as a non-root user, so software can't even modify itself.
Our software is not normally bundled like it is on windows, and that means the libraries are actually "shared" between a lot of software like it's intended to be and upgrading that library simultaneously upgrades all software on the system.
So you almost never have random outdated libs lying around from old software on your system, which is the cause of probably >90% of windows vulnerabilities.

So as long as you use the package manager to install your software you're pretty damn safe. Unless the repo itself is compromised, but if you're that paranoid there are ultra-autistic distros that can protect you from even your own package maintainers if you want to put in the effort.

The biggest vulnerability on GNU/Linux is 3rd party software you download outside the repo, like Steam games for example. And that's why I run Steam in a sandbox.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90974583
Linux malware isn't typically targeted at "end users" the same way windows malware is, however anyone telling you it's malware-free is an ignorant retard. Most linux malware targets webservers and things like that, but you would be a fool to think no one is hiding malicious packages in shiny things you would love to download. There have been cases where official software repos have been compromised with malicious packages as well.
Many linux distros come out of the box with no active firewall and no means to detect malicous software if a user runs any retarded shit they download. I'm not saying the OS is insecure, but you shouldn't buy into the myth that the OS is somehow protecting you from malware by being something other than Windows. You still need to be observant of the things you download and run on your computer.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90989652
Found a way to do it! As root I ran 
echo -e "default-server = unix:/tmp/pulse-socket" > ~root/.config/pulse/client.conf
and now paplay works.
I'm unsure if having root's server pointed to non-root user's socket is a possible security vulnerability. Please let me know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90989933
I think it should be fine because the daemon is running as an unprivileged user. The worst that can happen is you might accidentally change the permissions/ownership of the socket file which could prevent other users from connecting to it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90997661
I'm pretty sure it's possible, it's something I've wanted to try for a long time myself. You should be able to isolate the Nvidia GPU and pass it through to a VM while running your host system on the Intel gpu, so that's one possible option: https://github.com/BigAnteater/KVM-Laptop-GPU-Passthrough

Alternatively, I think you can run your desktop session off of your host iGPU, then use a tool like Bumblebee to do shit with your Nvidia GPU. Seems like someone got something like that working: https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=273121 . For Wayland, you might need this tool in specific: https://github.com/pedro00dk/nvidia-exec. I think you might need to blacklist the Nvidia driver from loading, then load it once your desktop session has started, then use Nvidia-exec to utilize the Nvidia card.

I don't think there's any way to get around using Nvidia drivers one way or another, though. It may honestly be less hassle to just give in and use the proprietary drivers altogether, I've seen people say the GNOME Wayland session is pretty usable on Nvidia.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91007217
One reason for that is that in wayland either only supports hardware accelerated graphics (opengl, vulkan) or raw pixel manipulation. So programs are mostly written in opengl/vulkan and opening such windows can be slow because how bloated graphics drivers are and they dont care about the opening speed of applications as much as the performance, so they create redundant buffers and stuff that improve performance but is slower to startup.
X11 on the other hand has xrender, which gtk and qt applications use and they have a smaller overhead when creating a window.
So I dont think it can really be fixed, too bad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91008449
(xrender is hardware accelerated but it doesn't have the same overhead as pure opengl/vulkan applications).

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html

Removing the web search in Windows Search should be as easy as:
>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows
>Add a new key called Explorer or if it exists enter it
>Make a new DWORD called DisableSearchBoxSuggestions and set it to 1
>Restart PC

>>91006213
I've been administering Windows machines for 30 years, I can explain this to you. Group Policy sets values in the registry, that then set other values - for example, there's a policy to force a certain wallpaper, which will set something in the *\Policies\* subkeys, which will ultimately map down to setting HKCU\Control Panel\Desktop!Wallpaper.

Why do they do it this way? Firstly, the Policies keys in the registry are ACL protected, so only administrators can change them: this is what makes them "policy" rather than just "configuration". Secondly, programs can also check the values in Policies to see if they're policy, and put up large friendly warnings that "This option is configured by your administrator" and/or lock out configuration screens. Thirdly, because the "real" setting is in the Policies keys, the real value is always available, and if they user is clever enough to (say) edit the registry and write their own value to HKCU, it'll be overwritten in the next Group Policy update.

Now, onto your problem: because you had no doubt set the policy in Group Policy Editor to "Disabled", this will actively remove any configured policy on the subject - so during a Group Policy update, any registry values outside of the Policies subtree connected to the policy would be removed. The anon above did what setting Group Policy to Enabled would do - which replaced your Disabled policy - and now it works to spec.

Here's how entries in Group Policy actually work:
>not configured: don't overwrite anything the user has configured
>enabled: overwrite user configuration with this option
>disabled: actively remove configuration of this option - usually manifesting as "force this option to defaults"

posts.com:
>>91006526
Logically, the one backing DisableSearchBoxSuggestions. Let's test that.
C:\>find "DisableSearchBoxSuggestions" C:\Windows\PolicyDefinitions\*.admx
---------- C:\WINDOWS\POLICYDEFINITIONS\WINDOWSEXPLORER.ADMX
    <policy name="DisableSearchBoxSuggestions" class="User" displayName="$(string.DisableSearchBoxSuggestions_DisplayName)" explainText="$(string.DisableSearchBoxSuggestions_ExplainText)" key="Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Explorer" valueName="DisableSearchBoxSuggestions">
C:\>find "DisableSearchBoxSuggestions" C:\Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-US\WINDOWSEXPLORER.ADML
---------- C:\WINDOWS\POLICYDEFINITIONS\EN-US\WINDOWSEXPLORER.ADML
      <string id="DisableSearchBoxSuggestions_DisplayName">Turn off display of recent search entries in the File Explorer search box</string>
      <string id="DisableSearchBoxSuggestions_ExplainText">

And there's your answer: it's the policy called "Turn off display of recent search entries in the File Explorer search box".

When I actually tried to get into all the fancy note-taking strategies and plugins, my actual productivity went down and I spent hours just jerking off over note taking.

Also I noticed most of the popular plugins for Obsidian kinda suck. The kanban board sucks, all of the Calendars suck (both of these plugins could be replaced by better software dedicated to them instead too). I actually wanted these things to be good, because it would be useful to easily link to note files from a calendar/kanban.

Really, you don't need all your notes to reference each other, or a complex tagging system, or any of that stuff. That adds on a bunch of extra time to anything you do. Maybe I'm a brainlet, but it's way too overwhelming for me.

Obsidian is actually what made me decide to switch to taking physical notes for anything I am not doing on the computer. My TODO lists, calendars, etc. are all just plans I have written down on paper. Yes I have to remember more, but that is actually kind of a good thing because it increases the amount of executive functioning I have to use so my brain doesn't turn into adhd zoomer mush.

I still use Obsidian but purely as a Markdown editor with links, and because OneNote is spyware. Probably switching to open source alternative to Obsidian soon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90999834
Yeah, I pretty much had the exact same experience and revelations, even down to your point about plugins being shitty (albeit, I was using Logseq, not Obsidian).

As much as my autism brain loves the idea of being able to jot down all of my disparate ideas and give them structure/link them together, it's too much effort. Frankly, I've found that with regards to note-taking, my goals are the following: to jot down an idea for later, or write something down for the sake of reinforcing the concept in my brain (and, there's actually some studies to suggest that jotting down notes on paper is superior for knowledge retention than taking notes on a computer). I find that if I need to refresh myself on a topic, it's easier just to look it up online rather than referring back to my notes. For jotting down ideas, text files honestly do the trick.

As far as todo stuff is concerned, I find that I'm by far the most productive with a simple todo list or sticky notes. I find them to be way more actionable, whereas drafting up some complicated, well-structured todo list with notes and comments gives me a false sense of accomplishment. Calcurse is honestly a pretty damn nice todo/scheduler application, but recently I've started using plain text files for my todo lists as well. Sometimes I worry that my life and work will get complex enough that I would benefit from having a tool like org-mode or something to tie it all together and structure it, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have started to use it for work this year. I have been using it for simple journaling on my personal computer for a while now.

I treat it like a wiki and a notes organizer in one. Process documentation, project notes, and snippets of code / screenshots in the same place, with the ability to link back and forth, and categorize each document. Tags and links are what really matters, and if that can be done with another program, so be it. This is just the easiest system I've found for that.

I find that most of my time is wasted on finding evidence as to "why" something is, not "what" it is. Sure, it would be nice if every project had obvious, long standing meaning, but I gave up on that long ago in the corporate world. So when some manager comes to me and says, "The customer really wants XYZ Report to show everything, fix it," my immediate response won't be, "What the hell is XYZ Report? I made that?"

I don't understand what most people are doing when I watch Youtube videos on the subject. Their complex systems and habitual note taking reminds me of the time when I bought a used college textbook and there were hundreds of post it notes inside, and half the text was highlighted - this person wasn't really taking note of the important things, it seems. Again, I just use it for hyperlinks between documents, and tags for categorizing each document. And the tags can even be hierarchical when you need them to be.

I said this in the past, but I'll say it again.

Functionality-wise, FFmpeg is a brilliant software project. It can do the most unimaginable things with media, it's widely used and it earned its reputation.

However, its CLI is just terrible. It's unintuitive and quite often poorly documented, people telling you to "just read the manpage bro" never tried doing something complex with FFmpeg or they are flat out lying.

Unfortunately, FFmpeg is far to widespread and established to change the interface now, so the only way to cope is through better documentation.

posts.sub: /iemg/ & /pmpg/ - In-Ear Monitor & Portable Music Player General
posts.com:
New OP same old /iemg/

How to request advice:
>Location
>Budget
>Source (phone, PMP, PC)
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Intended use
>Sound signature (or genres you like)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them

FAQs:
>Do I need a DAC/dongle?
Only if your source
• lacks a headphone jack
• has high noise/distortion (not uncommon with PC on-board audio due to interference)
• lacks power, i.e. your IEMs don't get loud enough
>Should I buy "X" FiiO/CCA/KZ product?
No. Despite their *previous* popularity and large number of *old* reviews, in 2023 these companies do not make competitive IEMs or DACs.
>Where do I buy IEMs?
Amazon, Aliexpress, Linsoul, HiFiGo, Shenzenaudio. Protip: IEMs routinely go on sale. November 11 is the biggest sale season!

Good overall guide if you're new to in-ear monitors:
https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu

>>90987430
IEMs are minimum phase systems, everything about how they sound can be derived from impulse response and distortion. This doesn't necessarily mean that you can EQ anything to sound exactly like something else as that can add distortion and physical factors like fitment and head related transfer function effect how it will sound on your ear vs the measurement device. Unless you're cadaver there is no way of confirming that the FR is the same at your ear drum.

the amd 7900xtx in an egpu has been confirmed to work with intel cpu. not found anyone yet using a ryzen setup.

AMD 7900xtx egpu with linux
Setup on Ubuntu 22.04
Install a 6.0+ kernel (using mainline for example), 6.1.4 in my case.
Install Mesa 22+ (using the oibaf ppa for example)
Install the missing amdgpu firmware from linux-firmware.git
Download the latest tag (for example 20221214)
Extract: tar xf linux-firmware-20221214.tar.gz
Copy the amdgpu firmwares: cp amdgpu/* /lib/firmware/amdgpu/
Install & configure egpu-switcher
Reboot and voila!

As far as I can tell, the overall experience is much better than with my previous GPU (NVIDIA RTX 2080):

No complex NVIDIA driver install.
No “plug the eGPU after boot” trick: you can have the eGPU plugged when the laptop boots, or at the grub screen. It just works.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90976878
Smartshift allows the GPU and CPU to talk with each other for better power management, basically. So if your GPU is under heavy load, it can borrow some power headroom from the CPU, and the other way around. SAM is AMD's marketing term for their version of reBAR, which gives you better GPU performance (in some scenarios, at least).

So technically you have the port the ssd currently occupies, which is a pci-e 3.0 x4.

You could potentially design and have assembled a custom pcb that drops in the wwan slot and breaks it out into another wwan slot and a sata m.2 slot.
It would be high effort and you're still left with a jank way of connecting the egpu but it's entirely doable.

The default mini-XLR is 3 pin only, for balanced you need a 2 ground then L and R so 4 poles
IEMS have a single side plug on each IEMs so making them balanced is completely trivial.

Now the better question to me is why instead of wiring off the plug directly some headphones wire the ground through the driver on the plug side for the non plug side.

If you're calling the HD650 "too messed up" in the frequency response that's likely a you problem and not a headphone problem. I'm an audio professional but I know word here doesn't count for much check SBAF and Gearspace if you don't agree with me personally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90989193
>Yes, I hate the autistic response of "Everything should be EQed"
I can see how the militantism can be annoying but it's generally in good faith and an attempt to spur people into trying it. The best argument against it is that it's still not that effective as a tactic and telling people that they can improve the sound of most headphones at literally no cost is a surprisingly hard sell, often they would much rather spend more money and get benefits that are largely imaginary. This is how the audio industry has always worked and it can be hard to come to terms with, many real audiophiles have lived out their whole lives with no real improvements.

However things are slowly changing. More value is being placed on measurements which means in the near future we may actually be able to buy headphones that are good enough that EQ is of no real benefit, note I don't mean Harman tuning but that's a whole different discussion. DSP is crutch being used to hide bad headphones but it does improve sound quality and it's good for the consumer who wants to easily switch from different preset sound profiles. Lifelike VR basically requires that HRTF variance is fully negated so continuous out-of-head localization can be achieved, research in that area should eventually see more funding. But for now, we live in the dark ages.

How do the SMSL DO/HO100 and Topping E/L50 stacks compare, more so in usage and features than sound which I doubt I could tell apart anyway?
Apparently the DO100 can do either line level output (no preamp) or variable level output (preamp) and feed both outputs (RCA and XLR) simultaneously whereas I couldn't find any info on the E50 doing line level meaning it's always a preamp, also I'm told it forgets volume levels between different outputs which also means it doesn't do them simultaneously.
For the amps on the other hand the L50 has a pass-through when it's off meaning I could theoretically also play around with a tube amp added to the stack at a later point, also the balanced out is 4 pin XLR, whereas the HO100 is the terminus for the audio signal and has a 4.4mm balanced out.
I would have the amp hooked up to the DAC through XLR as well as active desktop speakers hooked up to the DAC through RCA in either scenario.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Posting an update on the x15 earbuds I got for christmas. Not because anything's broken, I just wanted to report some more things about them.
I don't use them as extensively as most people probably do, but I have yet to burn through the charge on the case (in almost a month). The buds themselves I can attest last at least 2 and a half hours, maybe more but I haven't worn them for that long in one go. If you used them this long every day you'd probably burn through the charge of the case much quicker, I think it eats up like 6% or 7% for that amount of time.
One of them sits a bit flimsily in my ear, not a huge deal but if I'm wearing a hood I get anxious about it falling out.
And my initial thoughts on the touch controls remain the same, they're awful. They only work in one small center part of the earphones, which does at least mean that once you know how you can semi-reliably avoid touching them when you put them in your ears. But actually using them? Don't. It's all done through tapping (one tap = pause, two taps = previous/next depending on the earbud, three taps = audio up/down depending on the earbud), but it's so fucking hard to hit it right because the touch area is so small. You'll think you got it to go to the next track but no it just paused. Just use the controls on your phone and pretend you earbuds don't have touch controls.

It's hard to pick just 1 item so have 3:

Easily the best €15 I spend on a certified /csg/ meme product, especially as today you can't seem to get the Wiha bit version anymore. I've been using it for years now for all my tech repairs and cleaning disassembly.

>5 meters of double sided velcro
Cheap as fuck, only ordered it to meet coupon value requirements but hot damn it's useful and changed my cable management. No more dealing with annoying tiewraps which are a massive pain in the ass when you need to add or remove a cable later on.

>Kokko overdrive pedal

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90987607
>This ozone stuff sounds like such snake oil bullshit.
I can guarantee you ozone is not bullshit, use it for what it's good for. It's one of the most powerful oxidizers that exist, you can't even store it very long because it's that reactive. I use it to disinfect water in containers for ultrasonic misters. Standing water starts stinking quite quickly but ozone destroys everything in there, even biofilms (which sodium hypochlorite / bleach is unable to). I also use it to reduce airborne mold spores and bacteria in my lab, but I use an ionizer for that which also releases traces of ozone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90991317 (me)
One more thing, ozonated water is used extensively in the food industry to clean produce and meats because unlike bleach, it doesn't leave residues. In the US it is legal to bleach e.g. chicken meat but in other parts of the world this is not legal.

>>90998016
>what am I in for /g/? I'm a 22 year old zoomer that hasn't been around these things since I was 5, am I in over my head already?
depends on what kit you're working with and what CRT you end up with

many/most didn't have HDMI, and it's rare to find anything with a newer port. if you're stuck with HDMI as your video-out, then you'll need a converter or a second step (VCR, whatever) that accepts HDMI.

some CRTs did come with HDMI, though it's not common. I've seen plenty with SCART S-Video, and DVI. I've used S-Video CRTs as monitors in a pinch when my proper monitor died. Can't recommend using a TV as a monitor though.

Some CRTs have a habit of generating static build up. They might not be a good choice if you're working with sensitive electronics.

Most CRTs "whine" in my experience. I can hear them running. some people can't hear it and doesn't bother them.

note that they're heavy and take up a fair bit of space when compared with modern screens, but that's kinda obvious

consider just grabbing one from an ewaste facility; there's hundreds available. although you'll probably have to make a few trips depending on whether the one you chose even works.

Tor browser on Ubuntu only routes traffic through Tor if it's from the browser itself. Everything else goes through the clear net. Tails routes everything on the system through the Tor network. Whonix is set up in a similar way but takes advantage of VMs rather than Tails running in memory only.

It all started to fall apart when around that time a legislation that required all isps and mobile network providers to analyze and store all of their user data(an absolutely unrealistic request, still not fully implemented to this day)was passed. Afterwards there was a huge public scandal when some political activist got sent to prison for posting a meme with a swastika on VK, any kind of hentai became considered cp, for example. Also trying to ban telegram and failing spectacularly. And that's just of the top of my head. Nowadays it exists as only a shade of it's former self, unusable without a vpn.

tl;dl stop romanticizing the russian internet, it has died a long time ago

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91004522
It's not really. It used to be you couldn't join the Grenadier Guards in the UK unless you were over 6ft 2. The minimum height requirement is now 5ft 10. Other guards regiments don't have such stringent requirements. My brothers old regiment, the Irish Guards have had fellas in it from 7ft+ to just over 5ft.

With the likes of the Grenadiers and other ceremonial guards regiments, it makes tailoring ceremonial uniforms less hassle and cheaper if everyone is about the same size (which means you just have to let cuffs and trousers down, or up an inch or two). With a whole bunch of fellas of all different sizes you have to start having bespoke uniforms tailored. So having a few outliers in a regiment that carries out ceremonial duties when not deployed isn't too much hassle until you start getting a whole lot of fellas in of different heights.

Having all soldiers be over a particular height could be about anything from cutting down on outfitting costs, to simply having taller soldiers be more intimidating. When Japan surrendered at the end of WW2 they had to walk past 8 guys who'd been hand picked because they were all over 6ft tall to allegedly emphasise the Allied superiority and to intimidate the Japs. Pic related is the Japanese contingent coming on board the USS Missouri and the video here shows them coming on board and walking through the sailors. https://youtu.be/4EqRTWMVqMY?t=120

Depends on what games engine should be supporting. Not everything has to be able to support everything. With limited game variety you can size project down to something a little bit harder than CMS, see RPGmaker if it can be treated as semi-game engine.
People like to think they can start with big project and learn a lot by doing it, but reality is that big projects most of the time demand much more knowledge, skill and technologies, meaning you are overwhelmed, need to learn several things at once and you spend almost all the time trying to learn instead of producing anything, and doing something without seeing any products of your labor kills motivation extremely quickly. READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90992201
A static IP address is configured directly on the device itself (so, your server). If you have not done that then the IP address is not static. When you plug something into your home network it gets an IP address assigned automatically, most likely from your router. A DHCP reservation is when you configure your router to give a device the same IP every time. If you have not done this either for your server, then it's entirely possible that the server was simply assigned a different address.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90992201
>>90992274
Oh also, if you're using your router to assign IPs automatically you may be able to log in to its web UI and have a look at what IPs it has currently assigned to devices, which might give you the server's address without having to physically connect to it again. Depends on what router you're using though.

posts.com:

you are looking for a "DHCP Reservation"
this means that every time that specific mac address asks the DHCP server for an IP address, the server will respond with the same IP.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90992390
DHCP just assigns addresses as needed, it does not always assign the same one unless you tell it to by making a reservation. You can assign a static IP on your server and it will no longer use DHCP, but if you do this you must make sure the static IP is outside of whatever range of IPs the DHCP server assigns, because if it's not it's possible that the static IP you assign will conflict with the same IP being assigned to another device by DHCP.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90992390
find what network card your ubuntu box is using with the command
ip link
open up your netplan config file
sudo nano /etc/netplan/01-config.yaml
(it may have a different name. once you type /etc/netplan press tab twice to see what files are in the folder, and choose the one that looks the most like "config.yaml")
it may look like this inside the file:
network:
  version: 2
  renderer: networkd
  ethernets:
    ens3:
      dhcp4: yes

if not, that's ok - you just need to make it look like this
network:
  version: 2
  renderer: networkd
  ethernets:
    ens3: # this MUST be the name of your network card that you found out in the ip link command
      dhcp4: no
      addresses:
        - 192.168.0.150/24 # put whatever IP address you want it to have here, it must have /24 at the end and it must be on the same range as your network (ie: 192.168.x.x)
      gateway4: 192.168.121.1 # this is the IP address of your router, usually 192.168.0.1 or similar
      nameservers:
          addresses: [8.8.8.8, 1.1.1.1] # you can make these any DNS server you want, but cloudflare and openDNS are good enough


you don't need to set static IPs on the router, although I would consider it best practise as it avoids conflicts. but you have 252 addresses to play with (255 excluding broadcast, router, and your windows machine's IPs) so if it doesn't work, just try a different one. The router won't hand out an IP that is already being used, so a conflict would only happen if you assign it an IP that is already in use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90997416
and a quick note on nano controls just in case you aren't familiar
control + x will save and exit, asking you for confirmation first
shift + arrow keys will highlight text
control + k will cut the highlighted text
control + u will paste the test you cut with control + k
control + c will exist without saving
control + o will save without exiting

I consider nano to be the more user friendly option to vim, as you can just type without needing to enter insert mode, and the controls are painted on the screen. anytime someone tells you to use vi or vim, consider using nano if you get stuck on vi/vim

sudo netplan apply

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90998927
enough wattage to power your devices, and then check the runtime.
pretty much any UPS from a well-known brand is perfectly fine (eaton, apc, cyberpower, dell)
ones that are online won't have any switching time, meaning your stuff won't experience a momentary power failure while the UPS kicks on.
All UPSs are seal lead-acid, so don't bother looking for lithium-ion ones. this is because lead-acid has a 0% chance of catching fire, while Li-Ion has a non-zero chance of catching fire
remember that just because your computers PSU is 750w, it's not going to pull 750w. your average computer will probably cap out at 400w, monitors at 50-100w and things like routers/switches probably around 30-50w. always check the actual power draw before buying the UPS though

but basically make sure it has
>enough ports
>enough watts (VA is basically irrelevant, check the wattage)
>enough run-time
>online and interactive
not sure how it is elsewhere in the world, but here in australia all our power outlets on the wall are 10a sockets - a lot of UPSs have a 15a plug, which has a bigger earth spade and wont fit in a regular 10a plug. bigger UPSs still (2000w and up) tend to have 3-phase plugs, as well.

posts.com: what benefits do I have running wangblows server edition as a proxmox vm? I'm not looking for an alternative to linux, I'm just curious

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91004713
>benefits
you can run things that depend on .net without much hassle
if you prefer the windows GUI then thats a benefit
otherwise it's just significantly more performance overhead for pretty much no real gain. there is a headless version of windows server, but it's moreso for running things like active directory or msa databases. powershell is pretty barebones compared to something like bash, so you can't do a whole lot through the shell

basically unless you have stuff that needs/runs better on windows server, there isn't much point using it except for a general familiarity (say you are new to linux and want something close to windows)
but at that point you might as well just run a windows host and use hyperV or something rather than proxmox

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

Pfsense is gonna be able to see all subnets. Just don't expose the web ui on the ones you don't want.
Just like how you can choose which Ethernet adapters you want the DHCP server to run on. vlans are like virtual ethernet adapters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91004058
>>91005219
Honestly, I don't think you want to go down the clan path. Just use wireguard as a separate network. You can set up firewall rules between the physical and virtual (wireguard) network. More overhead but way easier to set up and way more useful for secure networking, not just on your local network but anywhere from any device you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90961090
Depends on whether it is traditional/convertible/detachable (example: Touchscreen on X1 Carbon vs. X1 Yoga vs. X1 Tablet)
While touchscreens on detachables & convertibles are self-explanatory (convertibles are heavier and bulkier for tablet use), touchscreen on traditional laptops are kind of mixed:
>it is nice to have feature, and come handy for some usage, but practically not really that useful for most usage. Inherent shape, form of traditional laptops limits the flexibility on how you use the touchscreen.
>while touchscreen on traditional laptops could do the same like convertibles & detachables (even handwriting, drawing using pens/stylus), you will find it inconvenient to open your screen 180 degree lying flat on the table, or just around 90-140 degree on table for gentle touchscreen gesture for some web browsing instead (take care on the hinges)
>while on convertible Yoga you could just open it 360 degree and hold it more firm, or on detachables simply detach the screen from the keyboard and it is lighter than convertibles. Also both have build-in stylus housing.
Also note that Touchscreen quality on traditional laptops differs to the convertibles & detachables. For instance, I find the Touchscreen quality on X1 Carbon is slightly lower than X1 Yoga like color coverage, etc (while Screen quality of X1 Carbon still miles above the common T/X series). Classic traditional laptop stays to be used traditionally (keyboard mouse) while convertibles/detachabes are designed to utilize more the touchscreen. And in some cases, Touch panels are higher quality compared to non-touch panels (generally, Lenovo make it that the higher screen resolution is, the higher the quality is)

I would say that the T23 would probably be best if you plan to use legacy hardware. It had both a serial port and a parallel port, could run Windows 98 or Windows XP competently, and of course is built like a brick shithouse.

If you can find a docking station then I’d recommend a T60. You lose the Windows 98 capabilities (it CAN be done but it doesn’t behave well) but you have access to a serial and a parallel port. I remember the ATI driver for my T500 crashed all the time on XP but behaved perfectly fine in Windows Vista and 7.

I use a multipen at work with 5 colors to keep track of work stuff in my day book. By default, every thing is in black. Meetings in purple, projects and keywords in green, people and annotations in blue, dates and decisions made in red. Kindof like syntax highlighting. It helps me skim based on whatever I'm looking for. I even write little table of contents on a per-month basis.
Specifically, the pen is a Coleto 5-Color Multi Pen. It's pretty cheap plastic though and I write like a neanderthal so they break in just over a year typically. The pen refills I use are called Hi-Tec-C, 0.4mm. They're overpriced imports from Japan, but great color and feel pretty good. I know there are better writing experiences out there, but this has proven the most handy for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90990100
- Slow compilation.
- Shared ownership and cyclical data are hard to work with.
- It's underspecified what's allowed in unsafe code.
- Immature ecosystem.
- Creating new error types is tedious, and errors don't have tracebacks (by default). (These are solved by third-party libraries but that's not ideal.)
- Macros can't inspect types, limiting their utility and encouraging fragile assumptions about names.
- Some useful things can't be abstracted over. You may have to write the exact same code twice for immutable and for mutable references. (Workarounds like macros and crazy type system tricks are a pain.)
- Some parts of it are still missing. Fallible allocation is primitive, const generics can't use most features, specialization is unstable. They're being worked on but they haven't arrived yet.

>>90990253
Is that really true? I've only seen it for projects that use unstable experimental no-guarantees features, and projects that use a modified toolchain.

>>90991773
C++ programmers are scared of using string_view because normal string manipulation becomes risky. Rust programmers aren't, the compiler can check it and worst case scenario you do a copy.
C++ programmers struggle with data races because people don't understand what shared_ptr does and doesn't synchronize or forget that a property was implemented as a bitflag. Rust checks it for you and catches these mistakes.
C++ makes trivial everyday code risky, Rust limits the risk to FFI and container implementations and such. And you can see the results in practice, Rust projects really do have fewer issues. Many of them don't need unsafe blocks at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91001890
() => 'greeting' defines a function that returns the string greeting.

A map is an association from key to value where both key and value can be of any type.

The function in the question is used as a key to the value "Hello world" so calling get with the function as the lookup key will indeed return the string hello world.

This is what ChatGPT said about it:
The code snippet appears to be written in JavaScript. The const keyword is used to declare variables that are immutable, and the ()=> syntax is used to define arrow functions. The Map object is a built-in JavaScript object that stores key-value pairs.
In the code snippet, the first line creates a new Map object and assigns it to the variable myMap. The second line defines a function and assigns it to the variable myFunc. Then the function is used as a key to add a key-value pair to the map object.
In the comments, the first line will return undefined as it is trying to get the value of the key 'greeting' which does not exist in the map.
The second line will return the value 'Hello world!', as it is trying to get the value of the key myFunc which is in the map.
The third line will return undefined as it is trying to get the value of the key, which is an anonymous function which also does not exist in the map.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90986520
>Any tips on what brands or hardware specs I should look for at minimum if I want a phone that'll feel smooth for at least 3 years or so?
You need at least 6GB of RAM. 5G isn't necessary but it's good to have so you can future-proof yourself.

Snapdragon 695, 750-778, 855-870 are all very usable in this day and age. Exynos is generally not great. Mediatek and Helios are super low budget and shouldn't be considered. Dimensity is Mediatek's forray into flagship chips and its pretty good from what I seen.

The amount of megapixels on a camera don't determine its quality.

Not every phone has a headphone jack or SD card slot, so it's up to you if that matters.

Android apps support most versions of Android but if you want to make sure you have access to all the apps, the later version you have, the better.

Updates are nice but they are not the end all be all.

Some cool new features:
>foldable screens
>120hz
>fingerprint scanner
>wireless charging
>reverse wireless charging
>face unlock
etc.

>>90987791
>rhythm games
You want iPhones for that. Even the best Android phones perform worse than iPhones.

If you must have Android for whatever reason (e.g. headphone jack), make sure the screen's structural integrity isn't fucked (so no Pixels, for example). I remember Huawei phones being particularly good at that. You'll also want the phone's general structural integrity to be good (or just have a really thick case).

Rhythm games are also a legit justification for custom ROMs (unless the game blocks rooted devices, but I haven't seen a rhythm game do that so far). Clean Android ROMs in general are good, too.

If your rhythm game has flicks then you'll want a phone with a higher ppi. This is a legit justification for QHD or 4k (so an Xperia 1 II would be good for that).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Long time iPhone SE (2016) user who recently switched to Pixel 4a for "muh freedoms" reportan.
Is bad battery life a feature(tm) of Android, or is it a custom ROM issue? Had Graphene at first, but the Signal web socket notification drain was taking 30%+ of my battery a day, so I moved to Calyx because of microG. Hooray, the Signal battery drain is no more but now by the time my battery dies after ~2 days, about 60% of the drain was caused by "Android System" and "Phone idle". So STILL, over half of my battery usage is coming from idle processes.
Meanwhile my iPhone SE (a phone that is four years older) would drop maybe 10% a day from idling. To be fair, this is with battery saver on, but that just brings another issue up. On my iPhone I could enable battery saver with no sacrifice to notification reliability. Meanwhile on Android, if I use battery saving mode then I'm liable to receive texts up to 30 minutes late. Hell, even WITHOUT battery saver on I will occasionally just not receive a text until I unlock my phone. Yet on the iPhone I never once had a late notification, with or without battery saving mode enabled.
Generally speaking I do prefer the Android experience, especially with custom ROMs that trim down a lot of the fat, but at the end of the day I need something that I can rely on when it comes to basic functionality. USB file transfer is a huge plus over iOS (particularly as someone who doesn't use cloud photo storage or music streaming shit), but that's tangential to the core feature-set of a PHONE.
I don't want to switch back to iPhone because I hate the walled garden bullshit, but sometimes it feels like the best option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91000066
Ultra wide band.
Lets devices very easily locate each other and securely transmit data.
It's been used so far for trackers, which already worked via bluetooth but with UWB you can actually get a perfect direction on them so your phone can show you arrows pointing to it with AR.
Smart cars, very few of them, can use UWB to automatically unlock your car if your phones near.
Also supposedly the smart home sector will eventually switch to using it to control things, because instead of hopping through a bunch of menus you can just point your phone at the device and control it that way. But we're still years out from any of this shit mattering to most people or being available really. Just future proofing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91001610
I have this alesis dm7, it takes up maybe 1.2m^2 so not too big. the pads are all a single velocity, no zones for the ride (edge/bell) or snare like fancier kits, though it does detect snare rim separately. The hat pedal is also not quite continuous, only outputs closed/half-open/open afaict. The single crash cymbal does have a choke sensor if you grab it in the right part but it doesn't work in addictive drums by default; might be able to midi map it but haven't yet.
Even with those limitations it's still more flexible than the 6 pad thing. I think you'd need at least 10 zones or to cover basic kit sounds. If you are space constrained you could pick up finger drumming on a small pad like that apk mini or a launchpad or whatever. no drum sticks but can still be satisfying imo.

For the guy asking in the last bread. Those are Genelec 8020s. The 8010s are not an option imho and yes they work well as desktop speakers. Yo will miss some deep bass without a subwoofer but I do not care since I have a bigger setup in the living room. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91007585
ACPI and UEFI aren't what makes PC OS's work on any PC, it's the fact that PC's are PC's
PC is an architecture, not just the cpu, but everything else needs to be PC-compatible as well, such as certain basic peripheral capabilities and addresses, the memory map, etc, etc, all the basic stuff in the the same place on any PC, which is what makes them PC's and any OS at least try to work, with only drivers needed for additional hardware
there's no reason a group couldn't make a de-facto standard architecture for ARM-based machines as well (even cellphones), but i'm not aware of any just yet

I think your judgment is in question so I simply can't take you seriously. Here let me help:

Here are reasons why AR might be concerning without the use of dicks:

>Constant surveillance: AR glasses can potentially record and transmit live footage of everything a person sees, which could be used for surveillance and tracking.

>Loss of anonymity: AR glasses can be used to identify individuals by matching their facial features to a database, potentially compromising their anonymity.

>Location tracking: AR glasses can be used to track a person's location, which could be used for targeted advertising or other unwanted purposes.

>Data collection: AR glasses can collect a large amount of personal data, such as browsing history, search queries, and personal information, which could be used for targeted advertising or other unwanted purposes.

>Hacking: AR glasses can be vulnerable to hacking, which could allow malicious actors to access personal information, control the device, or even see what the user is seeing.

>Misuse of data: AR glasses can be used to collect sensitive data, such as health and financial information, which could be misused if not properly secured.

>Ethical concerns: The use of AR glasses could raise ethical concerns about the balance between personal privacy and the benefits of technology.

You can fix this fuck up
>Install redirector
>Example url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/somepage
>Include pattern: https://en.wikipedia.org/w(iki)?/([^#?]*)(#[^?]*)?$
>Redirect to: https://en.wikipedia.org/w$1/$2?useskin=vector$3
>Pattern type: Regular expression
And there you go, you will now be redirected to ?useskin=vector which uses the legacy (ie better) skin. Fuck Jewpedia btw.

>>91005902
It theoretically could be a bit different at start of the stream, but as you go on those differences would pile on to produce a completely different output. In practice RNG should be done in integers in the first place. And precision is a different issue, yes, same noise will be slightly different at half and at full precision, but I specifically mentioned precision, as it will affect output in more ways that just altering precision.
