posts.sub: Anyway I can recover files on a dieing mechanical drive?
posts.com:
Im having issues recovering files from my mechanical external drive and im probably fucked, but maybe one of you nerds would happen to have any suggestions I can still try.

I have an iomega external mechanical drive I have been using for years, im sure far out of its warranty period. I had been meaning to get a replacement for a while and finally did and was going to begin transferring stuff over, but I think i waited too long and now im fucked.

I have 3 issues il try and break it down as:

1: Its mostly text documents I had on it that I care about, the rest is replaceable. I opened up one of the documents to make an addendum to something, tried to save it after, and was getting a message popping up saying like it couldn't complete the process and then I stupidly closed the file to try and reload it, but now the WordPad document is completely blank except for its file name and shows as 0 bytes. I have looked up 0 byte errors and have tried chkdsk on the drive (which is coming up with a bunch of "File record segment ___ is unreadable" messages and looked to be correcting some errors, but then had an unexpected error and stopped, this also did not fix the now blank document. Ive also tried the error checking tools in windows on the drive and it was unable to complete anything on the drive. Is there anyway that Windows 10 would have saved a "snapshot" of the time I did have that file open when it was working? I could just copy the text off it if so even if it was still fucked. I havent powered down my PC completely since and I didnt see anything in my tempfiles folder like I usually can find documents closed, but not saved.

That same issue similarly leads into (continued)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91007224
2: So I was pissed that that file was seemingly lost, but whatever, I can save the rest. Well when I began transferring files onto my PC from the external drive, I started getting a bunch of stuff that I just could not access. Even trying to right click on a folder slowed everything down to a crawl and I got a error message (think it was like cyclical exception something?) or a message saying the document was unable to be opened. I also had at least 4 folders completely vanish, like there isnt even a trace of them I can access, its like the folder and everything inside was deleted (and I double checked my recycling bin, they are not there). So im assuming those files/folders that wont open and the ones completely missing are not readable on the physical section of the external drive. My theory, is that from what I recall, each of those folders and files had some little diagrams either in them on attached that I had made in MS paint and for whatever reason, thats causing the fuck up, because I noted it was all files/folders I recall having them (though some not embedded into the Word Document were recoverable). So in this scenario, assuming the drive can access the files, but the paint images are fucking it up, is there anyway I could open these files via some other means or just so I can copy the text portions off of them? Like via a script or command line function that would extract it?

And finally (continued):

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91007236
3: Assuming the drive is completely fucked and I wanted to pursue trying to recover the files, is there any possibility? Are my files still likely on the drive, but the mechanical mechanism is borked and needs repairs? And if so, is that something that I will need a professional to do or is it user serviceable? I was also looking at these "data recovery" software ads, are these scams or do they actually work? And if so, would they likely have any effect on my drive that probably has a mechanical issue rather then just fucked files? Would it solve my issues restoring the files that are now blank and listed at 0 bytes? I really dont want to buy this stuff, but I will if they have an actual success rate to them, but likewise, does any open source/free software exist that is worth trying first? I really dont care if I lose the other stuff on the drive, but I will keep fidgeting around with shit if it means a chance at recovering the important text documents I had on here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91007224
Here's how I recovered most data from a failing drive a few years ago.
1. Power off immediately.
2. Use another computer to prepare a live Linux USB and a second, larger drive with empty space.
3. Now boot the computer with the failing drive from the live USB.
4. Use ddrescue to image the failing drive onto a file on the second drive.
5. Mount the file from the second drive with kpartx and copy the files out at your leisure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90996574
The identity function is such a "compression" scheme.

I presume you're not looking for error-correction (as in RAR with CRC checks and stuff), but rather something that always succeeds in decompressing (which RAR doesn't, since there might be too much corruption to correct)?

I do not know any compression schemes with that property, but it's not that hard to create one, either from scratch or - if you want the easy way - by altering an existing scheme like LZW:

1) Define a default decompression dictionary,
2) If a file has no embedded decompression dictionary (or it appears corrupt), use the default one, and treat the entire file as compressed data (no dict).

>>90997485
nta, but I can see the point made by >>90997459 that there are very few languages that manage to be both simple and usable -- perhaps tiny Lisps are the only ones.

The issue is that while you can remove Accidental Complexity from a programming language, you can't remove Inherent Complexity.
And given the design constraints of modern, general-purpose languages, I'd say the Inherent Complexity is quite large indeed.

Sure, you can design a simple language. Then people come to you wanting multi-threading support, formal semantics, native interop, metaclasses or higher-kinded types, and an official standard library with all kinds of bells and whistles... and soon you'll have created a monster that surpasses even sepples.

Procedure.i FindRemotePEB(hProcess.i)
  Protected pi.PROCESS_BASIC_INFORMATION
  Protected retLength.i = 0
  Protected opResult.i  = #False

  opResult = NtQueryInformationProcess_(hProcess, #Null, @pi, SizeOf(PROCESS_BASIC_INFORMATION), @retLength)
  ...
  ProcedureReturn pi\PebBaseAddress
EndProcedure

Procedure.i ReadRemotePEB(hProcess.i, *peb.PEB)
  Protected opResult.i   = #False
  Protected pebAddress.i = FindRemotePEB(hProcess)

  If Not pebAddress
    ProcedureReturn #False
  EndIf
  opResult = ReadProcessMemory_(hProcess, pebAddress, *peb, SizeOf(PEB), #Null)
  ...
  ProcedureReturn *peb
EndProcedure

posts.com:
>>91002896
>Header-only C++17 library provides static reflection for enums, work with any enum type without any macro or boilerplate code.

enum_cast obtains enum value from string or integer.
enum_value returns enum value at specified index.
enum_values obtains enum value sequence.
enum_count returns number of enum values.
enum_integer obtains integer value from enum value.
enum_name returns name from enum value.
enum_names obtains string enum name sequence.
enum_entries obtains pair (value enum, string enum name) sequence.
enum_index obtains index in enum value sequence from enum value.
enum_contains checks whether enum contains enumerator with such value.
enum_type_name returns name of enum type.
enum_fuse allows multidimensional switch/cases.
enum_switch allows runtime enum value transformation to constexpr context.
enum_for_each calls a function with all enum constexpr value.
is_unscoped_enum checks whether type is an Unscoped enumeration.
is_scoped_enum checks whether type is an Scoped enumeration.
underlying_type improved UB-free "SFINAE-friendly" underlying_type.
ostream_operators ostream operators for enums.
bitwise_operators bitwise operators for enums.
containers::array array container for enums.
containers::bitset bitset container for enums.
containers::set set container for enums.

has most functions you want (and more) implemented already, requires C++17 and I presume it uses your macro solution so they are compile time limited, not runtime.

posts.com: Every Windows application, without exception, uses dynamic linking. Windows does not have a stable system call interface, and therefore, all functions which execute a syscall instruction are provided through DLLs, such as kernel32.dll. To do pretty much anything interesting -- access the filesystem, network, etc -- it is necessary to interact with the kernel through these DLLs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91006461

>there's no common OS that i know of which doesn't use dynamic linking
True, but this is not just "supports dynamic linking". This is "required to use dynamic linking". You can write a Linux application that is fully statically linked. No references to any .so objects anywhere, not even libc. You can static link libc through musl, and you can even write your own functions that execute the syscall instruction because the ABI is set in stone. Even if they add new syscalls in the future, the read() syscall will always be performed on x86_64 by putting 0 in the rax regsiter. Write will use 1, open will use 2, and so on. That is stability.

Windows does not have stability in this sense. If you try to interface with the kernel in this manner, it is possible for your application to get bricked on a Windows update. Your only safe choice is through system DLLs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91006418
if windows programs were statically-linked, wine wouldn't be possible, since wine is, basically, a set of libraries
it actually has no syscall support, which is fine, because windows programs basically never actually make syscalls, instead they dynamically link in a library which acts as a proxy for syscalls, which wine can take the place of
this is why anti-cheat stuff is an issue, because they are one of the rare cases of programs actually doing syscalls themselves directly

posts.com:
>>91003447
Most "western" countries have data retention laws, that oblige network operators and others, to store client data. It is not actual texts or calls usually, but it definitely is metadata like time of connection, location, who you connected and so on. This is my experience of working for tc operator in central european country, we stored said data for 6 and then after law changed for 24 months.
That means your location, connection etc is connected to your identity, there is no issue connecting your identity to signal message sent or received and in cooperation with big tech owning the servers signal operates on, I believe it is not a problem to link your identity to your complete signal communication metadata.
Message is still encrypted, but especially in us, it can give law enforcement enough of probable cause to just seize your hardware and get all your messaging from it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Let me define what is social media.

Social media are Web 2.0 Internet-based applications.
User-generated content (UGC) is the lifeblood of the social media organism.
Users create service-specific profiles for the site or app that are designed and maintained by the social media organization.
Social media facilitate the development of online social networks by connecting a user's profile with those of other individuals or groups.

For example, a news website with a comment section using third parties software (like Disqus) isn't considered a social media, but a news website allowing users to submit content and hosting its own comment section and users profiles can be considered a social media.

>>90984094
Honestly, no. Personally I find it therapeutic when I do manage to get out of the house and being completely disconnected from it while just soaking in the reality around me. I'm on my desktop literally most of my free time. I don't really have a social life as people tend to avoid me because of my viewpoints with technology. I started to refuse to have full conversations around people who carried smartphones and valued my friends who would leave their phones at home or at least in their cars if we went for walks or hung out somewhere. Sadly, as the years went by more and more people who were my friends couldn't live without social media and their cell phones ignoring anything that I attempted to warn them about. Same happened with my family and now I can't even visit family without them all huddled around in a room talking about their Facebook feeds. I stopped going to holiday gatherings completely. I even set up an email to keep in touch with those who wanted to talk to me. Not one person be it past friends or family have ever sent me any messages. Instead they were simply only interested in messaging me if I had a Facebook account and the younger relatives would ask me about Instagram. Not listening to any advice or warnings I had. I never told them to flat out not own or use things just what these services were doing with their data and how much of a privacy concern it really is. Politely asking if they wanted me to discuss specific topics or to have real personal discussions to please not carry it with them, simple. In the end all of them just proved all of the dangers in the technology they chose to be addicted to as well as the services they gave their souls to.

>>90984624
I disagree with the necessity of x86. In terms of what it does I suppose I should be clearer. I think computers can ve classified as specific-purpose computers or general-purpose computers. The DevTerm is a good example of a specific-purpose computer. If you want a nice, ultra-mobile environment to write and compile LaTeX documents, it might literally be the best computer in the world for that owing to its nice keyboard and wide screen which give like a 2 monitor workflow to a UMPC which I think is unique to that device currently. If you want a computer which basically just bootstraps you into Chrome so use can use social media or into Steam so you can play games, I do not think the DevTerm would even be capable of it. So I wonder, is this a UMPC or is it a digital typewriter? I am inclined to call it a UMPC because it can run gfortran and gcc and other compilers. If it had no access to compilers I wouldn't call it a UMPC.

Steak Deck is another UMPC-ish machine that qualifies as a specific-purpose computer. It's job is run Steam games. I don't know if it can run compilers. I will assume the answer is yes. I still would not call the Steam Deck a UMPC, because it has no good way to get input without attaching peripherals, or worse, docking it. It is a game console that can run a C compiler by happenstance, not a machine designed to make doing so comfy. Consequently Steam Deck is not a UMPC. It is a games console.

I think to call it a UMPC you should be able to operate it with no peripherals, and it should be able to compile.

The GPD Win 3/4 could be seen as a general-purpose UMPC. It has both a nice way to make input without attaching peripherals and it can run compilers, or entertainment software.

(Cont)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90986613
I think if a UMPC is specific-purpose or general-purpose is a question of how many things it does well. Under a certain threshold is specific-purpose, above it, general-purpose. I don't know exactly where the threshold should be, but I think the ability to use both compilers and have input without docking/using peripherals are both core to if something can be called a UMPC or not. Lacking either should disqualify a device from the definition.
